reviews.review_msg: Pretty good. Lectures sometimes are too long, and he can go on tangents. The first midterm was tough, however, all other assignments are pretty reasonable.

Fred is a nice guy, but this is probably the worst class I have ever taken. There are 4 useless assignments that he (and the TAs) fail to explain well. The assignments are also due in multiple parts so there's basically one thing due every other week in addition to the weekly writing assignment. Lectures are confusing and unrelated to the exams.

I had mixed feelings about Fred's lectures. Some could be quite interesting, but he has a habit of halting too often to ask the class pointless questions or for awkward group "discussions" that weren't very fruitful. Seemed like the TA's weren't always on the same page as him. His assignments were very fair and relevant, though.

Fred seems like a nice guy, but the only thing keeping me going to lecture was his pretty face. I found myself quite bored in lecture and honestly the textbook was more useful and clear. Boring assignments that were somewhat unclear (though he tries to explain them) and four of em, but it is a W class. Probs wouldn't take this class with him again.

Like other commenters, for a writing course, it was relatively easy. However, there is a large amount of work. As a prof, he's still new, and doesnt clarify his assignments well. but he does well enough in lec to keep up with as he doesn't go off-topic very often.
One of the easiest writing intensive course in Communications. 'nuff said.

This professor has no respect to his students and don't expect to get any help from him. He cares more about defending himself than helping you to learn. If he says anything terrible to you, don't take it personally and don't let it bother you. He might have a PhD but he certainly didn't receive any education on how he should respect his students.

He's a very knowledgeable guy. Comes off as somewhat disdainful towards students but maybe that's because he gets so many stupid questions from people who weren't listening. Anyways, it was nice to do a video project. Learned a lot in this class although it was challenging to grasp  concepts sometimes.
Roy is an awesome pro I have ever had in SFU! He is funny and passionate in the course! He doesn't make the lecture too stressful! He is helpful and really nice guy!
Knows how to deliver course material in way that makes it easy to understand.

(I took this remotely because of COVID). He was a serious gem. He's knowledgeable & makes the lectures interesting. The readings are interesting too. Make sure to keep up with the annotations & exercises because it helps when final paper time comes around. He's also super understanding & caring if you need an extension. 1 of my fav profs for sure!

I absolutely loved this Prof. He was so articulate, interesting, intelligent, and had relevant examples that helped us understand new media issues in meaningful ways. Easily my favourite professor I've ever had.

Demands a lot in papers and even proposals. A long email was usually sent to the whole class after every proposal/paper submitted about how our papers didn't satisfy, while he didn't make clear what he wanted beforehand and often got us confused. Told us lecture attendance was counted towards final grade in the end of term w/o prior notice.

Very articulate and passionate about the topic and his work. Impressive since it's his first semester teaching at SFU. Showed helpful relevant examples in class. I hope to take more courses from him! Course mainly depended on doing well on the term paper and writing assignments.
Good lectures, though a little light on student involvment

Her lectures are hard to understand shes not very clear and rambles alot, she doesn't give lecture slides until after the lecture. We were given 3 writing assignments where 2 were due one week after the other, we also had a video project and midterm. Courtney, the TA for this semester was great though! no final as well

Svitlana is super nice & definitely passionate about what she teaches. She cares about her students and will help them out with any questions or concerns. She is very soft spoken so it is sometimes hard to understand what she is saying. Also, her lectures at times are confusing & all over the place so I had to rely on my TA to grasp the concepts.
The amount of work is expected for this course. Amazing TAs. He's pretty average professor, if you do your work then you can get through this class easily. Not much to be said here.
Worst Prof at SFU. Can't even believe they let this guy teach. It's totally impossible to understand him and his TA ended up teaching the whole course by himself.

This class was incredibly frustrating. We often didn't get any feedback at all â€” just a grade with no explanation or suggestions for improvement. If you want to ask questions during office hours, good luck. The professor seems very busy and you have to schedule a meeting ahead of time, which isn't always easy.

The grading criteria were super unclear throughout the semester, and it often felt like we were guessing what the professor and TA actually wanted. Average grades for most assignments hovered around a C- or even lower, which made it feel like the whole class was set up to struggle.

This has been the most disappointing and painful course I have taken at SFU. The professor obsession with APA formatting has completely strayed from purpose of teaching. There was no feedback on any assignment throughout the entire term. You never knew what you did well, what needed improvement, or why you received the grade you did.
She is as*.
She would never reply to any of my emails we've i sent them throughout the week
Super strict. Always obsessed with the specific details of APA.

I really enjoyed Dr. Cameron's class and found the lectures engaging and easy to follow. The assignments were straightforward and graded fairly. I would definitely take another class with Dr. Cameron given the opportunity.

Layla Cameron is very knowledgable and I found her lecture content to be pretty straightforward. We were only marked by 5 reading response essays and 3 big assignments throughout the semester. The grading was fair and overall I learned a lot about information technology.
Jean would go off on a lot of tangents, that would kind of take up a lot of class time however they were generally interesting although not always helpfulrelated to what we were studying.

Professor Hebert turned out to be a really awesome teacher. Although this class has quite a lot of projects, they're reasonably sized and manageable. Jean's teaching style is pretty fun and his lectures are interactive, which is neat. I thought his grading was completely fair.

His slides are horrible and he goes through them really quick that it's impossible to copy anything down. He does try to be a good professor and tries to make things interesting but I think the course is just boring overall. I wouldn't recommend taking his class though. He's too new and seems very disorganized and scattered.
